analytic.title: A Semi-Integrative Approach to Understanding and Intervening on False News Sharing

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Study concept and design: A.G.. Data preparation and acquisition: A.G. and A.N.T. Data analysis and interpretation: A.N.T and D. D. Manuscript-draft: A.G.

abstract.p: The risks of false news-its potential to distort public opinion and erode trust-have driven extensive research on potential countermeasures. Yet, there has been no comprehensive, comparative, and computational investigation of false news sharing and how to mitigate it. To address this, we apply a semi-integrative experimental approach that directly compares multiple false news interventions, examines individual-and item-level modifiers of intervention efficacy, and uses computational modeling to uncover the decision-making processes underlying these effects. We find that warning labels and media literacy interventions most effectively improve news sharing quality, followed by a social norm intervention. Accuracy prompts were least effective. Supporting generalizability, intervention effects remained consistent across individualand item-level characteristics, including age, analytical thinking, and political-lean. Supporting specificity, each intervention influenced news sharing quality through distinct decision-making processes. By applying a semi-integrative approach, we offer an in-depth understanding of false news sharing and how to mitigate it.

div.p: . As a result, researchers and practitioners have developed a wide ranging toolbox of psychologically informed interventions that show promise in addressing gaps in the identification and moderation of online misinformation (e.g., Lewandowsky et al., 2021;Kozyreva et al., 2024;Roozenbeek et al., 2023;Van Bavel et al., 2021).

Psychological factors play a significant role in misinformation spread, including false news sharing (Ecker et al., 2022). Confirmation bias and political polarization encourage people to share belief-aligned news (Osmundsen et al., 2021), cognitive laziness leads to difficulties in truth discernment (Pennycook & Rand, 2019), reward-based habits encourage unreflexive sharing (Ceylan et al., 2023), and people believe misinformation even after it has been debunked (continued influence effect; Lewandowsky et al., 2012). Nonetheless, intervention research has had some success at tackling false news, for instance, applying warning labels to misleading posts effectively reduces belief in and spread of misinformation (see Martel & Rand, 2023b). Despite this, warning labels have limitations; they require changing existing media environments and an objective criterion to identify false news, such as manual fact-checking. As a result, their applicability and scalability may be limited, particularly when compared to interventions that aid or empower individuals to make more accurate sharing decisions (e.g., nudging or boosting interventions; Hertwig & Grüne-Yanoff, 2017;Kozyreva et al., 2022). Such interventions include, for instance, prompting individuals to focus on the accuracy of information (e.g., Pennycook & Rand, 2022), forewarning individuals that they might encounter misinformation (inoculation and prebunking; Leder et al. 2024;Lewandowsky & van der Linden, 2021;Roozenbeek et al., 2022b), informing people of social norms against sharing false news (e.g., Andi & Akesson, 2020;Gimpel et al., 2021;Pretus et al., 2022), and media literacy trainings (Guess et al., 2020). Each of these interventions has been shown to increase truth discernment and reduce false news sharing (for an overview, see Kozyreva et al., 2022).

div.head: The One-Shot Problem
div.p: Despite these advancements, research on false news suffers from a "one-shot" or "one-at-at-time" problem-a problem that is widespread in psychology and more generally in the social sciences. While replicability and reproducibility initiatives have strengthened research practices (e.g., Nosek et al., 2022), psychological studies still largely remain narrow and suffer from a lack of systematic integration (the "one-shot" problem; e.g., Almaatouq et al., 2022;Muthukrishna & Henrich, 2019;Newell, 1973;Van Bavel et al., 2016;Watts, 2017;Yarkoni, 2020). For instance, it is common practice for independent research labs to conduct limited, singular experiments in which only a few parameters are included and design choices are selected unsystematically (e.g., Roozenbeek et al., 2022a). This one-shot problem holds true for false news research (e.g., Guay et al., 2023). Few studies have compared the effectiveness of various false news interventions (though see Fazio et al., 2024 for a large-scale comparison), and it remains unclear which interventions are effective for which audiences. The parameter space around false news interventions is largely undefined, and results across studies reveal inconsistencies (for a review, see Ecker et al., 2022). For instance, it is contested whether people's susceptibility to false news is driven primarily by cognitive complacency (e.g., Pennycook & Rand, 2019) or political ideology and myside bias (e.g., Roozenbeek et al., 2022a;Van Bavel et al., 2021;Van der Linden, 2022). Inconsistent findings like these are rooted, in part, in the practice of conducting one-shot studies.

To address the one-shot problem in psychology and the social sciences, researchers can apply integrative approaches to experimental science (e.g., Watts, 2011). Integrative approaches or frameworks explicitly consider the experimental space surrounding a psychological phenomenon-for instance, the impact of varying manipulations, the time allotted to the task, the degree of incentives, and item-level and individual-level modifiers-thus, creating a parameter space around a construct or behavior (e.g., Almaatouq et al., 2022;Larson, 2013). With rapid advancements in data collection techniques (and sufficient financial resources), this approach is becoming more viable among researchers, who can now simultaneously deploy as many elements as an infrastructure can support (e.g., Almaatouq et al., 2022;Awad et al., 2018;Peterson et al., 2021). For instance, recent work has mapped out broad parameter spaces around moral decision-making (Awad et al., 2018), risky decision-making , group synergy (Almaatouq et al., 2021), and subliminal priming (Baribault et al., 2018). These efforts provide a much more detailed and in-depth picture into human behaviors (e.g., Watts, 2011).

div.head: An Integrative Approach to False News Sharing
div.p: To begin to address the one-shot problem in false news research, we apply elements of integrative experimental design to false news sharing. Our approach considers the parameter space around false news sharing, including potential interventions to mitigate this behavior (Almaatouq et al., 2022;Watts, 2011). Specifically, we integrate three experimental components-each well-supported by empirical research but typically studied in isolation-into a unified framework.

First, we apply a multi-treatment design, estimating the average treatment effects of multiple manipulations by employing a multi-arm approach that directly compares several established false news sharing interventions (e.g., Milkman et al., 2022). Second, we examine effect heterogeneity, assessing how news sharing and intervention effectiveness varies across participant-level and stimulus-level characteristics by considering individuals' attributes, such as age and gender, and news items' attributes, such as the degree of sensationalism or political-lean (e.g., Baker, 2001;Bryan et al., 2021). Third, we investigate the underlying mechanisms, applying computational modeling to uncover the decision-making processes that drive false news sharing and intervention effectiveness (e.g., Fudenberg et al., 2020;Ratcliff et al., 2016). By combining these three well-established experimental components, we offer a uniquely broad insight into false news sharing and, crucially, how to mitigate this behavior.

The first component of our approach is a multi-treatment or comparative intervention design (e.g., Milkman et al., 2022). This method directly compares multiple theoretically grounded interventions to assess their comparative effectiveness, in the present case, in terms of their effectiveness at reducing false news sharing. By systematically manipulating these interventions, we can estimate causal treatment effects (average treatment effects; ATEs), and determine their relative impact. Despite its value, this level of comparative analysis-comparing the efficacy of numerous interventions-has been surprisingly underexplored in false news research; it remains unclear which interventions are more or less powerful than others at attenuating false news sharing (though see Fazio et al., 2024 for one large-scale comparison).

The second component of our approach maps the parameter space around false news sharing and false news interventions by considering how theoretically-motivated individual-and item-level characteristics modify these effects (effect heterogeneity; Bryan et al., 2021). At the individual level, this analysis identifies who is more or less at risk for sharing false news and how intervention effectiveness varies across individuals (personalized or fine-tuned interventions; e.g., . These modifiers include both demographic factors-such as age, gender, and income-and psychological traits, including cognitive styles, personality, and beliefs. At the item level, we assess how features of the news content itself predicts false news sharing and whether intervention effectiveness depends on these characteristics (item-response theory; Baker, 2001).

Item-level attributes can include, for instance, the sensationalism, political leaning, and familiarity of news articles. Crucially, we do not experimentally manipulate these individual-or item-level characteristics. Instead, we treat them as effect modifiers rather than interaction terms, as we do not necessarily assume a direct causal effect of these covariates on outcomes (VanderWeele, 2009;Hernán & Robins, 2024).

The first two components of our approach-multi-treatment design and individual-and item-level effect heterogeneity (e.g., Baker, 2001;Bryan et al., 2021;Milkman et al., 2022;-go beyond the scope of many one-shot studies in false news research. However, they leave an important level of analyses absent: the cognitive and decision-making processes that underlie news sharing behavior. As process variables inform precise psychological theorizing, the third component of our approach involves applying computational modeling to quantify the decision-making processes underlying false news sharing and the effectiveness of false news interventions.

To accomplish this aim, we apply drift-diffusion modeling (DDM), a well-defined modeling technique that captures the decision-making processes in choices (Fudenberg et al., 2020;Ratcliff et al., 2016). DDM can capture the choice of whether to share or not share a news item and how interventions influence such news sharing choices (Lin et al., 2023). DDM leverages participants' choices and response times to estimate three key decision parameters: the starting point-the overall initial bias towards one choice (share vs. not share news items); the drift rate-the information collected over time in favor of one choice (e.g., share) over another (e.g., not share); and the boundary separation-the amount of information gathered before making a choice (share vs. not share). By applying DDM, we can model the specific pathways that lead to news sharing tendencies (Mulder et al., 2012;Lin et al., 2023), how interventions shift these decision-making processes, and how individual-and item-level characteristics modify these processes to inform personalized and context-dependent intervention outcomes (Zhao et al., 2022).

Taken together, integrating these three experimental components into a unified framework provides a more precise and in-depth understanding of false news sharing. By simultaneously assessing the effectiveness of multiple interventions, the heterogeneity of these effects across individuals and news content, and the decision-making processes underlying these decisions, our approach offers a comparative, conditional, and mechanistic insight into false news sharing and how to mitigate this behavior.

div.head: A Semi-Integrative Approach
div.p: The present experimental approach aligns with but also diverges from previously proposed experimental approaches, in particular integrative approaches (e.g., Almaatouq et al., 2022;Watts, 2011). One key distinction is the inclusion of process-focused computational modeling, specifically drift-diffusion models (DDMs), which uncover the decision-making processes underlying a behavior or choice. Most existing integrative approaches do not incorporate this level of process-based analysis (e.g., Awad et al., 2018;Almaatouq et al., 2023).

Another distinguishing feature is its semi-integrative design. Unlike fully integrative or high-throughput approaches that require tens of thousands to millions of participants due to the extensive crossing of between-participant factors (e.g., Awad et al., 2018), our proposed approach does not systematically cross interventions or manipulations with one another. While this unfortunately reduces the dimensionality of the parameter space being mapped, it significantly lowers the required sample size and study costs, making the approach more feasible. In some situations, such as is the case for false news sharing, combining interventions (e.g., implementing both warning labels and accuracy prompts simultaneously) may offer only marginal knowledge gains while dramatically increasing complexity. Thus, our approach prioritizes maximizing knowledge acquisition while maintaining practicality and cost-effectiveness.

Despite going beyond one-shot approaches, we do not wish to overstate the novelty of our semi-integrative approach. The individual components of this approach-comparing multiple treatments, analyzing heterogeneity across individuals and stimuli, and applying computational modeling to capture process-level mechanisms-are all well-established research practices (Milkman et al., 2022;Bryan et al., 2021;Fudenberg et al., 2020;Ratcliff et al., 2016). Yet, studies that integrate all three components within a single experimental design remain rare (but see Zhao et al., 2022 for one example). Despite its availability, this experimental approach is often neglected in favor of top-down designs that focus on isolated effects and consider singular levels of analysis.

div.head: The Present Work
div.p: To reveal the comparative effectiveness of multiple false news sharing interventions, we included four empirically established approaches: accuracy prompts, warning labels, social norm interventions, and media literacy tips (see Kozyreva et al., 2022; see Methods for details; see Figures S1-S4). A no-treatment control condition was also included for comparison's sake. The interventions were selected due to their prominence in false news research (e.g., , their broad applicability (e.g., media literacy; e.g., Andi et al., 2020;Epstein et al., 2021;Mosseri, 2016), and prior mixed findings (e.g., accuracy prompts; Pennycook et al., 2020;Rathje et al., 2022). The interventions also represent a range of conceptual dimensions, differing in whether they are content-specific (e.g., warning labels applied to particular news items) or content-neutral (e.g., social norm interventions applied across all news items) (Kozyreva et al., 2022), and in whether they target the existing media environment (e.g., warning labels) or enhance individual decision-making skills (e.g., media literacy) (Hertwig & Grüne-Yanoff, 2017). Given this variation, the interventions were theoretically expected to load onto different decision-making processes as quantified by the DDM analyses. For instance, we expected warning labels to load more on the starting point bias (one's initial bias to share vs. not share) while media literacy tips should load more on the boundary separation (the amount of information gathered before making a sharing decision).

In terms of individual-level characteristics, we included demographic, social media use, and psychological variables that have been examined in previous false news research, for instance, age, political knowledge, time spent on social media, and political orientation (Bryanov & Vziatysheva, 2021;Sindermann et al., 2020). In terms of item-level characteristics, we included attributes quantified by an independent research group, for instance, the sensationalism, familiarity, and political-lean of the news items . Participants were preselected based on their propensity to share news online to avoid floor effects and to focus on habitual news sharers (Ceylan et al., 2023). Participants were asked to repeatedly choose whether to share or not share news items.
Our design involved both pre-and post-intervention trials and true and false news items.

This design allowed us to not only examine the comparative strength of several false news interventions but also the role of individual-level modifiers, item-level modifiers, and decision-making processes in true and false news sharing at three different levels of analysis: 1baseline sharing behavior before the interventions (pre-intervention), (2) the change in sharing behavior over the course of the task (time effect), and (3) the influence of the interventions on sharing behavior (intervention effect). Taken together, the present approach provides a uniquely broad, multi-level view of false news sharing; we reveal who is most likely to share false news, the cognitive processes involved, and how interventions shape this behavior across baseline tendencies, repeated exposure, and multiple intervention effects.

div.head: Participants
div.p: We planned to recruit 1,300 participants from the United States via Prolific, aiming for at least ~200 participants per condition after exclusions. This sample size was chosen to reliably detect effects of moderate or large magnitude, rather than very small effects that may be statistically significant but less actionable. In line with this reasoning, a sensitivity power analysis indicated that a sample of 200 participants per condition provided 93% power to detect intervention effects of small to moderate size (0.35 on probit scale; corresponding to 3-4 percent points marginal effect) and intervention-modifier effects of moderate size (0.3 on probit scale; corresponding to ~3 percent points marginal effect per moderator SD). This analysis was conducted by simulating datasets with varying effect sizes, each with 200 agents per condition, and applying the below described regression analysis to determine the effect detection (see Figure S5 and Supplemental Materials).

To avoid floor effects and intervene on habitual sharers of news (e.g., Ceylan et al., 2023;Guess et al., 2019), participants were asked in a pretest to rate how often they share news articles, ranging from 1 (never) to 5 (always). 1 In line with standard practice in intervention research to exclude individuals who weakly or do not exhibit the target behavior, only participants who responded 3 or above were invited to the study, resulting in a total sample of 1,321 participants (~66%; from 1,989 possible respondents).

Participants were excluded if they failed an attention precheck (n = 70), did not complete any part of the news sharing task (n = 99) 2 , completed only part of the news sharing task (n = 4), responded unrealistically quickly on the news sharing task (i.e., response time < 200 ms in more than half of trials; n = 4), responded unrealistically slowly on the news sharing task (i.e., response time > 30 s in more than half of trials; n =1), or because of missing data on one or more of the individual-level characteristic measures (n =1). The observed drop-out rate after having started the news sharing task (<.01%), was significantly lower than that observed in an alternate multi-intervention examination of false news sharing (~16.45%; Fazio et al., 2024). We also excluded 14 participants who reported their gender as nonbinary, as this small sample skews statistical models. The final sample included 1,128 participants (M age = 41.09, SD age = 14.19; 562 female).

Data Availability: All data and analysis files can be found on OSF. The study was preregistered at https://aspredicted.org/blind.php?x=6HV_3FD. 3 We confirm that we have reported all measures, conditions, data exclusions, and how we determined the recruited sample sizes.

div.head: Design and Procedure
div.p: Participants first completed a survey assessing potential individual-level modifiers, including psychological, knowledge, and demographic variables. Next, they completed the news sharing task, which included 40 unique news items: 20 pre-intervention and 20 post-intervention trials. The trials included both true and false news (Guay et al., 2023). In each trial, participants saw a single news item (headline and accompanying image; each unique news item was presented only once to participants; see Figure 1) and decided whether to share it or not. The five conditions (between participants)-accuracy prompt, warning labels, social norm information, media literacy tips, and a no-treatment control-were presented to participants at the halfway point (i.e., after 20 trials). News item-level modifiers (e.g., sensationalism, familiarity) were sourced from an independent sample. Descriptive statistics of all included measures are available on OSF under R Markdown.

div.head: Individual-Level Characteristics
div.p: We included demographic, social media use, knowledge-based, and psychological characteristics that have been examined in previous false news research (see Bryanov & Vziatysheva, 2021;Sindermann et al., 2020).
The demographic information consisted of age, gender, education, and political orientation.

Education was assessed via a 7-point scale: "What is the highest level of education you have completed?" (1 = High-School No Diploma, 2 = High-School Diploma, 3 = Some College, 4 = Associate Degree, 5 = Bachelor's Degree, 6 = Master's Degree, 7 = Professional Degree or Doctorate Degree). Political orientation was assessed using a 9-point Likert scale: "Where on the following scale of political orientation would you place yourself?" (1 = Extremely Liberal to 5 = Moderate to 9 = Extremely Conservative). Finally, we calculated a political congruency variable, which entailed the extent to which participants' political orientations aligned with the political leanings of specific news items (calculated by zero-centering both variables at the politically neutral point and then multiplying them).
We measured the quantity of social media use with four-items. Participants responded to:

"How often are you on on social media (eg. Facebook, Twitter)?", "How often do you post or share content on social media?" (1 = Never, 2 = Every few weeks, 3 = 1 to 2 days a week, 4 = 3 to 6 days a week, 5 = About once a day, 6 = 2 to 5 times a day, 7 = 5 to 10 times a day, 8 = Over 10 times a day), "On an average day in the past week, how many minutes would you say you spent on social media (eg. Facebook, Twitter)?" (open-ended response); and "Over the past week, how often did you get news from social media (eg. Facebook, Twitter)?" (1 = Never, 2 = Hardly Ever, 3 = Sometimes, 4 = Fairly Often, 5 = Very Often). The overall quantity of social media use was determined by averaging these four items, after centering around the mean and scaling the variables by their standard deviation. (Sirlin et al., 2021). The second media literacy measure was a four-item digital literacy quiz (e.g., "Which of the following four passwords is the most secure?" 1 = WTh@5Z, 2 = Boat1234, 3 = intro*48, 4 = 123456; Levin & Redmiles, 2021). The two media literacy measures were combined into a single measure by scoring incorrect responses on each of the five questions as 0 and correct responses as 1 and averaging across these scores. Political knowledge was measured using a four-item quiz on U.S. politics (e.g., "Whose responsibility is it to decide if a law is constitutional or not?" 1 = The President, 2 = Congress, 3 = The Supreme Court, 4 = The Parliament; averaged: 0 = Incorrect, 1 = Correct; Tappin et al., 2021).

For psychological variables, participants answered a three-item cognitive reflection test (CRT) that measures analytic thinking by using problems with intuitively compelling but incorrect answers (averaged: 0 = Incorrect, 1 = Correct; Thomson & Oppenheimer, 2016). They also completed a three-item misplaced certainty scale, which assessed their tendency to feel certain about claims that are opposed by counter-evidence or judged skeptically by others (e.g., "I feel certain about things that most people think lack clear evidence"; 1 = Never, 7 = Often; e.g., Gollwitzer et al., 2022;Oettingen et al., 2022). 4

div.head: Item-Level Characteristics
div.p: We considered six item-level characteristics of the 40 news items presented to participants.

We used item-level estimates from an independent sample (Pennycook & Binnendyk, 2022) to avoid biasing our participants' judgments by having them view the same headlines multiple times (e.g., rating believability before or after deciding whether to share). Because such consensus item-level estimates can shift over time, and as recommended by Pennycook and Binnendyk (2022), we ensured that our data collection (October 2022) occurred relatively close to when these estimates were originally obtained (January 2022).

These six item-level characteristics included: the news items' positive valence ("To what extent does this headline make you feel good [happy, excited, hopeful, etc.]?"; 1 = Not at all to 6 = Extremely), sensationalism ("To what extent is this headline sensationalist and/or exaggerated?"; 1 = Not at all to 6 = Extremely), perceived importance ("Is the headline important?"; 1 = Extremely unimportant to 6 = Extremely important), familiarity ("Are you familiar with the above headline [have you seen or heard about it before]?"; 1 = Not at all to 6 = Extremely), and political leaning ("Is the headline more favorable for Democrats or Republicans?"; 1 = More favorable for Democrats to 6 = More favorable for Republicans). From each news item's political leaning we also calculated its absolute partisanship (i.e., distance from politically neutral), ranging from 0 (Neutral) to 2.5 (Strongly favorable for Republicans/Democrats). Additional characteristics (e.g., negative valence) exhibited high multicollinearity and were thus excluded.

div.head: News Item Sharing Task
div.p: Participants read: "In this task you will see a series of news headlines that previously appeared on a social media feed (e.g., Facebook). For each news headline, you will be asked whether you want to share that news headline with other people. When doing so, please imagine that you are sharing (or not sharing) these news headlines on a real media profile you use." After a practice round (Figure 2), participants were informed that they would see 40 headlines, with a break after the first 20 headlines. The intervention treatment occurred during this break. The preand post-intervention blocks each included half true and half false news items, as well as half pro-Democrat and half pro-Republican items (per block: 5 true pro-Democrat, 5 true pro-Republican, 5 false pro-Democrat, and 5 false pro-Republican items). The order of these trials within the pre-and post-intervention blocks was randomized. For each item, participants decided whether to share the news item by clicking on either "Do Not Share" or "Share" (Figure 2).

The 40 news items were selected from a previously validated database of 200 items provided by another research group (see ; see Figure 1 for examples). A challenge in studying news sharing behavior is the potential for a low prevalence of sharing decisions. To reduce the risk of floor effects, we selected the 40 items from the 200-item database based on their higher likelihood to be shared (as rated by an independent sample) and ensured a balance in veracity (half true, half false) and political lean (half pro-Democrat, half pro-Republican). All news items were sourced from the internet and had previously been shared on social media. All false news items were fact-checked false by reputable third-party fact-checkers;
all true items were screened as true and selected from mainstream publications . See the R Markdown file on OSF for descriptive statistics of the news items.

div.head: Format of News Item Question
div.p: Note. The practice item that participants saw at the start of the news sharing task.

div.head: Interventions
div.p: After completing the 20 pre-intervention trials, participants were randomly assigned to a no-treatment control condition or one of four interventions: an accuracy prompt (e.g., Pennycook et al., 2020;Pennycook & Rand, 2022), warning label (e.g., Brashier et al., 2021;Martel & Rand, 2023a;Martel & Rand, 2023b;Mena, 2020;Pennycook et al., 2020;Porter & Wood, 2022;Sharevski et al., 2022), social norm (e.g., Andi & Akesson, 2020;Epstein et al., 2021;Gimpel et al., 2021), or media literacy intervention (e.g., Guess et al., 2020). 5 See Figures S1-S4 for materials of each of the tested interventions.

Accuracy Prompt Intervention. In the accuracy prompt intervention, participants judged the accuracy of a single news item with the goal to shift their attention towards accuracy while completing the news sharing task . Participants received the following instructions: "You are halfway through the task. We would like to pretest a news headline for future studies. We are interested in whether people think it is accurate or not. We only need you to give your opinion about the accuracy of a single headline. We will then go back to the primary sharing task." Participants then saw one of four politically neutral news items (two false and two true; taken from , and evaluated the veracity of the item: "To the best of your knowledge, is the above headline accurate?" (yes or no). Participants then received feedback whether their choice was correct or not. See Figure S1.

div.head: Warning Label Intervention. The warning label intervention consisted of a visual
div.p: warning label added to the false news items (adapted from Facebook's warning label; see Martel & Rand, 2023a). In the post-intervention trials, an overlay was added on top of the false news items: "False Information. Checked by independent fact checkers." The overlay was transparent to allow participants to still view the news item underneath, and was selected because Facebook was using this warning label at the time of our study (Martel & Rand, 2023a). Participants were not informed that these labels would be added to the false news items. Halfway through the task, and before the warning labels were applied, they saw only a message that read: "You are halfway through the task." See Figure S2. We would like to share some of our previous work with you. In an earlier study, we found that 98% of people think that it is very important to *only* share news articles on social media if this news is accurate." See Figure S3.

Media Literacy Intervention. The media literacy intervention provided participants with 10 media literacy tips for spotting and responding to false news online (taken from Guess et al., 2020), such as "Be skeptical. False news stories often have catchy headlines in all caps with exclamation points. If shocking claims in the headline sound unbelievable, they probably are," and "Some stories are intentionally false. Think critically about the stories you read, and only share news you know to be credible". See Figure S4.
No-Treatment Control. Participants in the no-treatment control condition read: "You are halfway through the task."

div.head: Overview
div.p: Our semi-integrative experimental approach allows us to uncover the comparative effect sizes, individualized intervention outcomes, and decision-making processes underlying intervening on false news sharing. We first examined news sharing behavior, followed by the processes underlying these decisions (using DDM). In both analyses, we considered three sharing contexts:

(1) 'baseline' sharing behavior before the interventions (pre-intervention), (2) the change in sharing behavior over the course of the task (time effect), and (3) the causal influence of the interventions on sharing behavior (intervention effect). We also examined the role of individual-level characteristics (e.g., age, political orientation, social media use) in these three contexts of sharing behavior. Because several item-level characteristics were found to be collinear with news Item Veracity (e.g., false news was generally rated as more sensationalist than true news), we examined item-level characteristics separately for true and false news. Finally, building on these analyses, we examined sharing behavior and intervention efficacy for two subpopulations that are particularly at risk of sharing false news: older individuals and conservatives (e.g., Guess et al., 2019).

div.head: Regression Models
div.p: We employed Bayesian generalized linear mixed-effect regression models to investigate sharing choices. In these models, we treated sharing ("not share"/"share") as a binary response variable via a probit link function. We analyzed our data in an analogous way to Signal Detection Theory (SDT) which teases apart the response bias (i.e., overall response tendency) and discrimination ability (i.e., classification accuracy) of participants (Macmillan & Creelman, 2004).
Specifically, we differentiated between overall sharing tendency ( ; sharing across true and false β news) and sharing quality ( ; sharing true over false news). β

Given the probit regression framework, the intercept of the model corresponded to the sharing tendency, and the coefficient describing the influence of Item Veracity (False = -0.5, True = 0.5) represented the sharing quality (for detailed description see supplementary material). As such, all predictor coefficients describe the influence on the sharing tendency except for predictors including an interaction with Item Veracity, the coefficients of which describe the influence on sharing quality. This approach aligns with recent analysis recommendations in false news research (Guay et al., 2023) and mirrors the approach used in signal detection tasks on false news detection (Sultan et al., 2022). Across our models, we accounted for individual differences in overall sharing tendencies by including random intercepts and differences sharing quality by including Item Veracity as random slopes for each participant. Additionally, we accounted for item-level differences by adding item ID as a random intercept in all models.

To ensure that the inferences did not depend on the model specification, we ran simpler models with each individual-level or item-level characteristic separately. Given that the results of simple and complex models align, we concluded that the models are not overfitting and that the inferences are robust. Additional model details are explained in the results section. For a detailed description of the model structures and robustness analyses, see supplemental materials.

div.head: Drift Diffusion Models (DDMs)
div.p: The main parameters of the mixed-effect Bayesian DDMs were estimated with the BRMS package (Bürkner, 2017). The BRMS package, which is a well-established and reliable tool for estimating DDMs, has been widely validated in decision-making research (e.g., Lin et al., 2023;Cochrane et al., 2023;Donzallaz et al., 2023).

We applied a regression framework for parameter estimation with the Wiener response distribution, which is essentially a nonlinear generalized regression of the joint response time and choice distribution, simultaneously estimating the main parameter of the models: starting point bias, drift rate, and boundary separation. This framework allowed us to estimate DDM parameters with regression predictors (see Boehm, Steingroever, & Wagenmakers, 2018;Vandekerckhove, Tuerlinckx, & Lee, 2011). The regression formula paralleled the regression models with some changes to account for the cognitive characteristics of the three metrics of DDMs. Specifically, we predicted start point, drift, and boundary separation in terms of: 1) pre-intervention, (2) time effect, and (3) intervention effect, using the formulas from the corresponding non-DDM regression models for each of the three main parameters.

In line with past work, we excluded all predictor terms with Item Veracity predicting the starting point or boundary separation because inferring the item's veracity is part of the evidence accumulation process; we only consider sharing quality when modeling the drift rate (Lin et al., 2023). One exception to this, however, was modeling the influence of warning labels; in this case, the accuracy of the item can be inferred at the start of the decision process (starting point) as the warning labels saliently signal the accuracy of the item.

We formalized the DDM as a hierarchical (i.e., mixed effect) model, by using the same random-effect structure as described in regression models. Given that the start point is restricted to the interval [0, 1] and the boundary separation must be greater than 0, we utilized a logit link function to model the starting point and a log link function to model the boundary separation.

Coefficients are reported on their respective logit and log scales. For a detailed description of the model specifications and the model estimates, see supplemental materials and Tables S4-S6, respectively. Figure S14 shows the parameter recovery analysis. For all parameters, the generating and recovered parameters were highly correlated, showing that each parameter describes a distinct mechanism and that their effect magnitudes are interpretable. Posterior predictive checks show that the DDM can recover population-level ( Figure S15) and individual-level ( Figure S16) choice and response time patterns.

div.head: All Models
div.p: To aid interpretability, all predictors in the models describing individual-or item-level characteristics were mean centered and continuous variables scaled by their standard deviation. In our analysis, we report the 95% credible intervals for each coefficient to determine whether the effect is credible, based on whether the interval overlaps with zero. Additionally, we provide evidence ratios (ERs), which are equivalent to one-sided Bayes factors, to quantify the relative posterior probability for a directed effect (e.g., an increased sharing tendency) compared to its alternative (e.g., no change or a reduced sharing tendency), offering a continuous measure of evidence (Krass & Raftery 1995). For predicted marginal effects of the interventions we report the median and the 95% highest posterior density (HPD). Note that while our research design allows for causal identification of the effects of Condition (the experimental interventions; ATEs), the reported relationships between behavior and individual-or item-level characteristics should be interpreted as descriptive rather than causal. This distinction is crucial because, unlike the interventions that were experimentally manipulated, the demographic factors were not manipulated, meaning that we cannot rule out all possible backdoor paths (i.e., confounding paths; Hernán & Robins, 2016;Pearl et al., 2016). All analyses were performed with the R package BRMS (Bürkner, 2017). Visual inspection of the chains and their Rhat values (Rhat ≤ 1.01; see Tables S1-S12) confirmed that all models converged.

div.head: Pre-Intervention
div.p: Model 1 investigated pre-intervention sharing tendency and sharing quality (in the first half of the task). The model included the individual-level characteristics as predictors (to investigate sharing tendency) and the two-way interactions between the individual-level characteristics and Figure S6). Figure 3A. For coefficients, see Table S1. For model predictions of the influence of individual-level characteristics on sharing decisions on a percentage scale, see Figure S7.

div.head: Time Effect
div.p: Model 2 examined the effect of time on sharing. Model 2 echoed Model 1, but we added Time (pre-versus post intervention) and the two-way interactions between Time and each of the individual-level characteristics as predictors to estimate the change of sharing tendency over time.

We further added the two-way interaction of Time and Item Veracity and the three way interactions between Time, Item Veracity, and each of the individual-level characteristics to estimate how sharing quality changed over time. To account for individual differences in sharing changes from the first to the second half of the task, we added Time as a random slope to the participant level Figure 3B shows that these β effects were largely independent of individual-level characteristics (see also Table S2)

div.head: Intervention Effects
div.p: Model 3 estimated the average treatment effects (ATEs) of the interventions by comparing participants' behavioral changes from pre-to post-intervention in each of the intervention conditions to the no-treatment control condition. Building on Model 2, we estimated the change in sharing tendency and sharing quality over time separately for control and intervention treatments, which allowed us to compute the contrast in this pre-post change between conditions, corresponding to the causal effect of the interventions (mirroring a difference-in-difference approach). In the model, this is achieved by adding Condition (no-treatment control, accuracy prompt, warning labels, norm intervention, media literacy tips; with control condition as the reference) alone and in interaction with the terms that included Time (pre-versus post-intervention). The moderating effect of those interventions was estimated by adding an interaction of this contrast (i.e., the difference-in-difference) and the mean-centered individual-level characteristics. See supplemental materials for a detailed description of the model and Table S3 for regression coefficients.

We observed significant variation across the interventions. Figure 4 shows the average sharing probability for true and false news, both pre-and post-intervention, for each intervention (as compared to the no-treatment control condition). Figure 5 shows the change in sharing behavior from pre-to post-intervention in each condition. Figure 6 shows the associations between individual-level characteristics and overall sharing tendency as well as sharing quality per intervention. We report the results for each intervention in turn. Figure 5A).

The smaller reduction in overall news sharing in the accuracy prompt condition was particularly pronounced for individuals with higher analytical thinking ( = 0.14, CI = [0.03, 0.26], ER >100; β Figure 6).

Regarding sharing quality, participants in the accuracy prompt intervention exhibited an increase of 1.4% points in news sharing quality from pre-to post-intervention. This increase did not credibly differ from participants in the control condition, who exhibited a reduction of 2% points ( = 0.08, CI = [−0.12, 0.27], ER =3.4; Figure 5B), indicating that the accuracy prompt β intervention did not successfully reduce false news sharing. The observed findings were consistent across participants' characteristics ( Figure 6). The marginal effect of the accuracy prompt intervention, as predicted by the model, is a 1.3% increase in sharing tendency (95% HPD: -0.6% to 3.3%) and a 3.3% increase in sharing quality (95% HPD: −0.3% to 6.9%). For model predictions of how the impact of the intervention varies across individual-level characteristics on a percentage scale, see Figure S8. Figure 5A). This effect was consistent across β individual characteristics ( Figure 6).

Regarding sharing quality, participants in the warning labels intervention exhibited an increase of 8% points in sharing quality from pre-to post-intervention. This increase credibly differed from participants in the control condition, who exhibited a reduction of 2% points ( = β 0.78, CI = [0.55, 1.00], ER >100; Figure 5B). This positive effect of warning labels on sharing quality was particularly pronounced for participants with lower levels of education ( = −0.25, β CI = [−0.46, −0.04], ER =85.2; Figure 6). The marginal effect of the warning label intervention, as predicted by the model, is a reduction in sharing tendency by −3.2% (95% HPD: −5.1% to −1.6%) and a 7.44% increase in sharing quality (95% HPD: 3.8% to 11.3%). For model predictions of how the impact of the intervention varies across individual-level characteristics on a percentage scale, see Figure S9. Regarding sharing quality, participants in the social norm intervention exhibited an increase of 3.5% points in sharing quality from pre-to post-intervention. This increase credibly differed from participants in the control condition ( = 0.35, CI = [0.16, 0.55], ER >100; Figure 5B). This β effect was consistent across individual characteristics ( Figure 6). The marginal effect of the social norm intervention was a small increase in sharing tendency by 1.0% (95% HPD: −2.9% to 0.8%) and a 4.5% increase in sharing quality (95% HPD: 1.3% to 8.0%). For model predictions of how the impact of the intervention varies across individual-level characteristics on a percentage scale, see Figure S10. β Figure 5A). This effect was consistent across individual characteristics ( Figure 6).

Regarding sharing quality, participants in the media literacy intervention exhibited an increase of 13% points in sharing quality from pre-to post-intervention. This increase credibly differed from participants in the control condition ( = 0.83, CI = [0.62, 1.04], ER >100; Figure β 5B). This effect was consistent across individual characteristics ( Figure 6). The marginal effect of the media literacy intervention is a small decrease in sharing tendency by 2.0% (95% HPD: −3.8% to −0.3%) and strong increase in sharing quality by 11.7% (95% HPD: 8.0% to 15.6%). For model predictions of how the impact of the intervention varies across individual-level characteristics on a percentage scale, see Figure S11. Figure S12). Moreover, we conducted additional analyses to ensure our inferences did not depend on a specific model specification. Specifically, simpler models run with each individual-level characteristic separately (i.e., only one characteristic as predictor per model) confirmed all findings described above ( Figure S13; see supplementary materials for model details). The consistent results from both the simple and complex models indicate that the models are not overfitting and that the inferences are robust.

div.head: Drift-Diffusion Models
div.p: We conducted mixed-effects Bayesian drift diffusion models (DDMs) to investigate the decision-making processes underlying participants' sharing choices. The model assumes that the news sharing decision process begins at a starting point or initial bias situated along a continuum ranging from "not share" to "share". The individual then accumulates evidence in favor of either option, which is represented by the drift rate. The drift in this context consists of two categories.

The first is the average drift towards "not share" or "share," which influences overall sharing tendency. The second is the change of the drift towards "share" or "not share" as a function of news accuracy influencing the sharing quality. Finally, the individual decides whether or not to share once they have gathered enough evidence. The amount of evidence required to reach these boundaries is quantified by the boundary separation. This approach aligns with that of Lin et al. (2023), which also examined false news sharing depending on Item Veracity via DDMs.
We developed an open-source Shiny app that visualizes these metrics and the impact of the tested interventions on these dynamics, see https://alan-tump.shinyapps.io/DSIA/.

div.head: Pre-Intervention
div.p: First, we analyzed the pre-intervention behavior across all conditions by estimating the DDM parameters (starting point, drift rate, boundary separation) with the regression formula used for Model 1 (see above Figure 7A). increased boundary separation-on average, these groups gathered more information before their sharing decision (see Table S4 for all statistics). Taken together, individual-level characteristics appear to meaningfully predict varying decision-making processes when making news sharing decisions.

div.head: Time Effect
div.p: To investigate the time effect with the DDM we included only data from the control condition (as was the case in the regression analysis) and applied the formula of Model 2. As in the pre-intervention DDM model, we excluded all terms containing Item Veracity for start point and boundary separation. We investigated how participants' starting point, drift rate, and boundary separation changed over time-from the first half of the experiment to the second half ( Figure 7B). Figure 7B). These results suggest that decision-making processes over time trend towards lower overall news sharing (across true and false news) but not necessarily higher quality sharing.

The observed effects were moderated by several individual-level characteristics (see Table S5). For instance, the increase in starting bias against overall news sharing over time was 54.6, respectively). Said another way, with increased exposure to news items, greater analytical thinking and education-level appeared to push participants towards more accurate news sharing when deliberating on the news items.

div.head: Intervention Effects
div.p: We examined how participants' DDM parameters were influenced by the interventions (Figure 8; Table S6) while accounting for the pre-intervention and time effects using the formula of Model 3, again with terms containing Item Veracity excluded for start point and boundary separation. However, we still include news Item Veracity to predict start points in the presence of warning labels as these labels saliently signal the veracity (see supplemental materials for model description). Figure 8B) (Lin et al., 2023). The accuracy prompt did not influence the boundary separation (β = 0.02, CI = [−0.02, 0.07], ER = 5.3; Figure 8C). These process results align with the observed non-credible effect of accuracy prompts on sharing behavior (in terms of sharing quality).

Individual-level characteristics impacted the starting point and drift rate in terms of overall sharing tendency (e.g., social media use, analytical thinking; see Figure 8A-B). Regarding sharing quality, the accuracy prompt's lack of influence on drift was fairly robust to individual-level characteristics, except that participants with lower levels of education showed a greater drift rate towards sharing quality after the accuracy prompt (β = −0.07, CI = [−0.14, −0.00], ER = 42.9; Figure 8B). This raises the possibility that accuracy prompts may be effective for less educated individuals (see also Figure 6) by changing their deliberation (what they think about) during the sharing decision. Figure 8B). Media literacy was the only intervention that increased the boundary separation, that is, led participants to deliberate longer before deciding whether to share or not (β = 0.12, CI = [0.01, 0.13], ER >100; Figure 8C).
