div.head: Item-Level Characteristics
div.p: Having considered individual-level characteristics, we turned to item-level characteristics, such as the sensationalism, importance, or familiarity of a news item. Unlike the individual-level models, these models included the item-level characteristics as predictors. Additionally, we examined true and false news sharing behavior separately instead of overall sharing tendency and sharing quality; exploratory analysis revealed that several item-level characteristics were collinear with news Item Veracity, which led to convergence issues when predicting sharing tendency and quality ( Figure S17-S19 Pre-intervention (the first half of the task), item-level characteristics did not appear to meaningfully impact either true or false news sharing behavior ( Figure 9A; Table S7; Figure S20).
The only credible effect was that participants shared more false news if its content was
Republican-leaning (as compared to Democrat-leaning) (β = 0.06, CI = [0.01, 0.12], ER = 79).

Item-level characteristics also neither interacted with the effects of Time (first to the second half of the task) on sharing behavior ( Figure 9B, Table S8), nor the effects of the interventions on sharing behavior ( Figure 9C; Table S9). The only credible results were that warning labels were Figure 9C). As we did on the individual-level, and to account for issues surrounding model specification and overfitting, we conducted regression analysis with each item characteristic separately.. These simpler models confirmed the above described findings (see supplementary materials and Figure S21).

Regarding the DDMs, we found no credible effects of item-level characteristics on the drift rate either pre-intervention ( Figure 10A; Table S10) or over time ( Figure 10B; Table S11). We also found little evidence to support news item characteristics as modifying drift in terms of the intervention effects ( Figure 10C; Table S12).

div.head: Tailoring Interventions to Vulnerable Subpopulations
div.p: Our semi-integrative experimental approach allowed us to identify which groups of people are more (or less) likely to share false news, and which decision-making processes underlie this behavior. In line with past research (e.g., Garrett & Bond, 2021), we find that conservatives are particularly susceptible to sharing false news (Figure 3). And, our DDM analysis suggests that this demographic group is characterized by a specific choice pathway: Their drift rate-what conservatives think about while making the decision to share or not share-appears to drive their lower sharing quality ( Figure 7A).

The applied semi-integrative approach can also inform which interventions are most likely to effectively improve the sharing behavior of at-risk groups, such as conservatives. We found warning labels and media literacy tips to be more effective than the social norm and accuracy prompt interventions, suggesting that the former may be better candidates. Moreover, the social norm intervention did not appear to be more or less effective as a function of political orientation.

Notably, while we found warning labels to be effective among conservatives, the beneficial effect of warning labels on the starting point was attenuated ( Figure 8A). That is, conservatives appear to continue to consider the content of news items even when they are clearly labeled as potentially false, suggesting that this intervention has a less direct impact on this specific group. In contrast, media literacy tips showed a promising trend to be particularly effective among conservatives ( Figure 6), specifically by increasing the drift towards news sharing quality ( Figure 8A). Media literacy tips may therefore be the best intervention for this at-risk group (at least when keeping variables outside of the scope of our study, such as potential scalability, constant).

To illustrate these results, and to allow researchers and policymakers to examine more fine-grained demographic groups (e.g., older conservatives; liberals with limited education), we created an open-source Shiny app (https://alan-tump.shinyapps.io/DSIA/) in which users can select specific individual characteristics and examine the effects of the tested interventions. The app serves as a rapid and intuitive way to assess intervention efficacy within various subsamples of interest, such as groups defined by age, gender, education, and political ideology. For example, Figure 11 shows how the app can be used to visualize the effect of the media literacy intervention on older conservatives' news-sharing behavior.

While the app provides valuable insights, we stress that it is purely descriptive-it visualizes patterns observed in our experimental data and does not generate out-of-sample predictions. Users must take into account sample sizes when exploring subgroups and that the results reflect the estimated percentage difference to a counterfactual population that received no treatment rather than precise predictive estimates. A more robust prediction of intervention effectiveness for specific subgroups would require accounting for interactions between predictors and non-linear effects (e.g., U-shaped age effects), which would necessitate substantially larger datasets. Given the size of our dataset (five between-participant conditions with ~200 participants each), such methods would not be appropriate. 6

Instead, the app provides a structured way to explore how intervention effects are strengthened or weakened for different demographic groups in our data, offering insights into how interventions might be tailored to specific audiences. These findings can help inform the development of targeted intervention strategies, which should then be empirically validated. In doing so, the app contributes to the broader trend of data-as-public-good in the spirit of open science, facilitating further hypothesis testing and scientific advancement (e.g., Vlasceanu et al., 2024).

div.head: Figure 11
div.p: Example of the Open-Source Shiny App for an At-Risk Group: Older Conservatives.

Note. The central panel compares evidence accumulation in the no-treatment control (solid lines) and the selected intervention (dashed lines) conditions. Sliders can be adjusted to investigate the influence of specific individual-level characteristics (here: older conservatives), and interventions can be selected from a dropdown list (here: media literacy tips). In this example, individuals in both conditions start their decision process relatively centrally. For true news the drift rate slightly trends towards "share" for individuals provided with media literacy tips (the green dashed line shows a slightly upwards trajectory), while those in the no-treatment control condition exhibit a slight trend towards "not share" (the solid green line). Conversely, for false news, individuals provided with media literacy tips exhibit a visually stronger drift rate towards "not share" (dashed purple arrow) than those in the no-treatment control condition (solid purple arrow). This difference in drift for true and false news is amplified by individuals in the media literacy tips condition accumulating more evidence before making a sharing decision, indicated by the larger boundary separation (dashed horizontal lines at the top and bottom of the DDM image), than those in the no-treatment control condition (solid horizontal lines). The panel on the right shows the predicted efficacy of the selected intervention as a function of the selected demographics.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The goal of this work was to provide a broad, multi-level account of false news sharing and how best to curb it. To achieve this, we applied a semi-integrative approach that combined three key experimental components-each well-supported by prior research but often studied in isolation-into a unified framework: (1) multi-treatment, directly comparing multiple false news interventions;

(2) effect heterogeneity, examining how individual-and item-level characteristics shape false news sharing and intervention efficacy; and (3) mechanistic processes, using computational modeling to uncover the decision-making processes underlying these effects.

The first component, which compared multiple interventions, revealed clear differences in their effectiveness. Warning labels and media literacy tips most reliably improved news sharing quality, followed by the social norm intervention. Accuracy prompts were the least effective. The second component, by incorporating individual-and item-level characteristics, shed light on both the risk factors for false news sharing (e.g., Baker, 2001;Bryan et al., 2021) and the potential for tailoring interventions to specific groups (e.g., . While some individual-level characteristics, such as conservatism, were associated with poorer news sharing quality, they did not meaningfully alter intervention effectiveness. This suggests that the most effective interventions (e.g., warning labels) are broadly applicable, including for at-risk populations.

Item-level factors, such as the sensationalism and political leaning of news content, also had little impact on intervention efficacy, reinforcing the robustness of the tested interventions across different individuals and news types. Finally, the third component, which applied drift diffusion modeling (DDM), revealed the distinct decision-making processes underlying news sharing and the interventions' effects. Different interventions altered news sharing in significantly different ways. For instance, warning labels reduced sharing by shifting the initial starting point of the decision process, discouraging people from even beginning to deliberate on whether to share the flagged content. In contrast, social norm and media literacy interventions improved sharing quality by influencing how participants weighed evidence during the decision-making process itself.
These findings suggest that combining interventions targeting different decision-making mechanisms may enhance overall effectiveness.

Taken together, our findings provide a broad and integrative perspective on false news sharing and how to mitigate it, with implications for reducing its harmful consequences, including misinformed political activism (e.g., Jacobson, 2023), poor health decisions (e.g., Loomba et al., 2021), and even violence (Lewandowsky et al., 2013) (though see Altay et al., 2023).

Simultaneously, the present work, along with several other examples (see Zhao et al., 2022), support the value of applying semi-integrative experimental approaches-for instance, systematically comparing multiple interventions, assessing effect heterogeneity, and examining underlying cognitive processes within a unified framework. These approaches provide a cost-effective way to move beyond the one-shot problem that plagues research in false news and the social sciences more generally-that is, the tendency for studies to test isolated hypotheses, consider only a few parameters, and rely on narrow, unsystematically selected design choices (e.g., Almaatouq et al., 2022;Watts, 2017).

div.head: False News Interventions
div.p: A key strength of the present work is the inclusion of multiple false news interventions within a single design (Fazio et al., 2024). Consistent with prior research, we find that warning labels, social norm cues, and media literacy interventions improve news sharing quality (at least in the context of a controlled experimental environment; e.g., Andı & Akesson, 2020;Guess et al., 2020). Accuracy prompts, in contrast, did not produce a meaningful change in sharing behavior.

While this appears to contradict past findings (e.g., , the observed effect size aligns with prior studies. For instance, Lin et al. (2023) found that accuracy prompts increased sharing discernment-in a DDM-based approach similar to ours-but the effect was small and emerged in an aggregate analysis across six studies (N = 5,338). Given that our design used a light-touch, single-headline accuracy prompt (whereas multi-headline prompts yield stronger effects; Epstein et al., 2021;Fazio et al., 2024) and a smaller sample than Lin et al. (2023), our study may have been underpowered to detect this subtle effect. That said, the practical significance of this smaller effect size remains an open question (e.g., Pretus et al., 2022).

The multi-treatment component of our semi-integrative approach allowed us to directly compare the effectiveness of multiple interventions. Warning labels and media literacy tips were similarly effective at improving news sharing quality, and both outperformed the social norm intervention, which in turn was more effective than accuracy prompts (which showed no meaningful effect). Notably, replicating past findings (Guess et al., 2020), media literacy tips were just as effective as warning labels, despite warning labels being highly salient and explicit ( Figure S2). From a theoretical perspective, media literacy tips qualify as a "boosting" intervention-one that enhances individuals' cognitive skills while preserving autonomy, rather than altering the external environment (e.g., Hertwig et al., 2017). Warning labels, by contrast, rely on an objective standard of accuracy, often determined through manual fact-checking-a method that is both resource-intensive and difficult to scale (see Martel et al., 2022;Stencel et al., 2021). These findings highlight media literacy tips as a particularly promising approach to combat false news, balancing effectiveness with practical feasibility.

div.head: Individual-Level Characteristics
div.p: The second component of our semi-integrative approach-examining effect heterogeneity-allowed us to identify which individual characteristics (e.g., age, gender, and political orientation) predict news sharing behavior and whether certain interventions are more or less effective for specific groups (personalized interventions; e.g., . At baseline (before any interventions), numerous individual-level traits predicted both overall sharing tendency and sharing quality. Identifying as male, being politically conservative, and lower analytical thinking (among other factors) predicted a greater overall sharing tendency (across true and false news). In line with past work, analytical thinking predicted greater sharing quality (e.g., Pennycook & Rand, 2019), as did liberalism (e.g., Guess et al., 2019), education-level, and political knowledge (Mazepus et al., 2023). Moreover, the positive effects of analytical thinking and education on sharing quality increased from the first to the second half of the news sharing task-as participants encountered more news trials (akin to scrolling through an online newsfeed).

In contrast, and surprisingly, political congruency-the extent to which a news item's political leaning aligned with a participant's ideology-was not associated with sharing quality (at baseline or over time). This suggests that poor news sharing quality is driven more by cognitive complacency and political identity than by political myside bias (e.g., Pennycook & Rand, 2019Roozenbeek et al., 2022a;Van Bavel et al., 2021;Van der Linden, 2022). More broadly, these findings highlight key risk factors for false news sharing, including being male, intuitive thinking, and identifying as politically conservative, while challenging the common assumption that people share misinformation primarily because it aligns with their political beliefs.

Although individual characteristics predicted both overall news sharing rates and sharing quality, they did not meaningfully alter the effectiveness of the interventions. Of the 40 potential moderation effects (10 modifiers × 4 interventions), four were marginal and only one was credible ( Figure 6): Warning labels were more effective in improving news sharing quality among less-educated participants. Given our statistical power to detect moderate-sized moderation effects (~0.3, see Figure S5B), it is possible that smaller effects exist but are unlikely to be practically meaningful. These findings strongly support the generalizability of the observed intervention effects across diverse individual characteristics, suggesting that the most effective interventions-such as warning labels and media literacy tips-improve news sharing quality broadly, including among at-risk subgroups such as conservatives.

div.head: Item-Level Characteristics
div.p: Our semi-integrative approach also accounted for item-level characteristics-an often overlooked level of analysis in one-shot psychological research (e.g., Clark 1973;Judd et al., 2012). In the case of news content, these characteristics include attributes such as the sensationalism, familiarity, and political-lean of a news item. Despite their potential relevance, and providing novel evidence for the item-level generalizability of false news interventions, these characteristics did not meaningfully alter intervention effects (Figure 9). This finding is notable, as it suggests that interventions remain effective across key news types, including sensationalist and highly politicized content. Nevertheless, as artificial intelligence advances, false news is likely to become increasingly sophisticated and harder to detect, potentially changing the nature of these null effects (Waldrop, 2023). Future research should examine whether the tested interventions will remain effective as misinformation evolves.

div.head: Decision-Making Processes
div.p: The third component of our semi-integrative approach used computational modeling, in the form of drift diffusion modeling (DDM), to uncover the cognitive and decision-making processes underlying false news sharing and the effects of the tested interventions. Doing so makes the present work among the first to systematically examine the choice processes underlying news sharing behavior (see Lin et al., 2023;Orchinik et al., 2023).

Overall Sharing at Baseline. We first considered the role of choice processes in participants' overall tendency to share news (both true and false news) before any interventions were introduced (at baseline). On average, participants began the decision-making process with a slight bias against sharing (starting bias) and became even less likely to share as they considered the news item's content (drift rate). These effects varied across individual characteristics ( Figure 7A). For example, younger participants exhibited a stronger initial reluctance to share (starting bias), liberals were more likely to suppress sharing based on content evaluation (drift rate), and older participants tended to gather more information before making a decision (boundary separation). These findings reveal that decision-making processes vary as a function of individuals' characteristics when making the decision to share (versus not share) news items.

Sharing Quality at Baseline. Beyond the general tendency to share news, decision-making processes also played a role in sharing quality before the interventions (at baseline). For instance, participants' consideration of the news items' content pushed them towards better sharing quality (drift rate; Figure 7A); this suggests that most people's cognition-what people think about when considering a news item-leads them towards sharing true over false news. This effect was especially pronounced among more analytical and reflective thinkers, liberals, those with higher education, and those with greater political knowledge-factors that appear to enhance the ability to discern false from true news. These findings help explain why some individuals are more susceptible to sharing false news. For example, people who rely less on analytical thinking (e.g.,

Pennycook & Rand, 2019) seem particularly vulnerable not because they share more news overall or because they fail to gather sufficient information, but rather because of what they focus on-or fail to consider-when making news sharing decisions.

The tendency for participants to exhibit better sharing quality as they considered a news item's content remained stable over time ( Figure 7B), suggesting that repeated exposure to news does not unfortunately, on its own, improve sharing quality. However, this null effect varied by individual characteristics-those higher in analytical thinking and education showed a stronger shift toward better sharing quality over time. This suggests that their cognitive approach to evaluating news becomes increasingly beneficial in environments where they encounter news repeatedly, such as online news feeds.

Intervention Effects. The tested false news interventions operated via distinct decision-making processes. As expected, the immediate salience of warning labels strongly deterred overall sharing and improved sharing quality early in the decision-making process by shifting participants' initial bias against sharing (starting bias; Figure 8A). However, this effect was less pronounced among conservatives and less-educated participants, who appeared to integrate warning labels into their decision-making later-during content evaluation rather than at the outset ( Figure 8B). This suggests that these groups continued to assess the content of news items even when a warning label was present, potentially allowing them to override the label if they found the content subjectively credible.

Unlike warning labels, the social norm and media literacy interventions primarily improved sharing quality by influencing how participants processed news content during decision-making (drift rate; Figure 8B). These effects were particularly pronounced among individuals with lower analytical thinking, suggesting that these interventions help this at-risk group (e.g., Pennycook & Rand, 2019) to change their thinking (or lack thereof) when deciding whether to share.

Media literacy tips-unlike any other intervention and consistent with previous theorizing (Guess et al., 2020)-also encouraged participants to gather more information before making a sharing decision (boundary separation; Figure 8C). This dual effect, increasing both deliberation (drift rate) and evidence accumulation (boundary separation), likely explains the intervention's strong overall efficacy. By prompting participants to weigh information more carefully before deciding, media literacy tips allow deliberation to exert a greater influence on sharing quality.

These findings not only clarify why, how, and for whom different interventions work, but also suggest which interventions could be complementary. While warning labels primarily influence decision-making at the outset, social norm and media literacy interventions shape what participants focus on when evaluating content. This highlights a key advantage of examining the cognitive mechanisms behind intervention effects-by understanding the underlying choice processes, we can better identify which combination of interventions maximizes efficacy.

div.head: Subpopulations At-Risk for False News Sharing
div.p: The semi-integrative approach we applied provides insight into which subpopulations are most at risk for sharing false news and why. Consistent with prior research (Guess et al., 2019), our findings ( Figure 3) indicate that conservatives are particularly vulnerable. Extending this work, we find that conservatives' lower news sharing quality ( Figure 3A) is driven by how they process information during decision-making-specifically, by what they focus on (or fail to consider) and
by their tendency to gather less information before making a sharing decision. Notably, this effect is not due to a greater initial bias toward sharing news compared to liberals ( Figure 7A).

Our approach also sheds light on which interventions are most effective for at-risk populations and how these interventions exert their effects. For instance, our findings suggest that media literacy tips may be the most effective intervention for conservatives. This intervention showed a promising trend of improving conservatives' news sharing quality ( Figure 6), specifically by influencing their deliberation during content evaluation ( Figure 8B). In contrast, while warning labels were similarly effective, conservatives continued to assess the content of flagged news items rather than dismissing them outright. This reveals a degree of nuance. While warning labels are similarly effective across liberals and conservatives, they have a less direct impact on conservatives, potentially because conservatives are more likely to distrust fact-checking efforts in general (Robertson et al., 2020).

To help researchers and policymakers examine specific demographic groups within our studied population (e.g., conservatives, older individuals, liberals with limited education), we developed an open-source Shiny app (https://alan-tump.shinyapps.io/DSIA/). This tool provides a dynamic, interactive visualization of the tested interventions' effects, showing how these effects vary based on individual-and item-level characteristics (Figure 11; see Vlasceanu et al., 2024 for a similar approach). The app updates a visual representation of the DDM dynamically, allowing users to explore which of the four tested interventions most effectively reduced false news sharing-and how they did so in terms of the underlying decision-making processes-for specific target groups. However, we emphasize that the app is purely descriptive-it visualizes patterns observed in our data and does not generate out-of-sample predictions. Its findings are constrained by the study's sample size and design, making it a tool for exploration rather than prediction.

Nevertheless, the app offers a structured way to explore how intervention effects may vary across demographic groups, providing insights that can inform targeted intervention strategies. By making the app openly available, we contribute to the broader trend of data-as-public-good, fostering further hypothesis testing and scientific advancement (e.g., Vlasceanu et al., 2024).

div.head: Semi-Integrative Approaches as an Experimental Method
div.p: Our work not only advances false news research but also highlights semi-integrative experimental approaches as a method for studying human choice and behavior. Much of the social sciences suffer from a one-shot problem-studies are typically isolated, singular experiments that examine only a few parameters and rely on design choices selected unsystematically (e.g., Almaatouq et al., 2022;Muthukrishna & Henrich, 2019;Newell, 1973;Roozenbeek et al., 2022a;Van Bavel et al., 2016;Watts, 2017;Yarkoni, 2020). The semi-integrative experimental approach applied here-combining multiple interventions, individual-and item-level modifiers, and computational choice modeling within a single framework-offers a way to address this limitation (e.g., Almaatouq et al., 2022;Larson, 2013;Watts, 2011). Similar semi-integrative frameworks as the one applied here could be applied to a wide range of domains. For instance, they could be used to study altruistic behavior and the effectiveness of prosocial interventions, or to examine more routine decisions, such as consumer choice. Supporting this broad applicability, semi-integrative designs have been applied successfully to compare multiple decision-making influences in simple contexts-such as evaluating how factors like recommendations, salience, and cost shape restaurant choices (Zhao et al., 2022).

Although integrative designs afford broader insights into psychological phenomena than narrow, single-effect studies, they have some costs. Primary among these is increased complexity, both in design and analysis, which typically necessitates larger sample sizes to achieve statistical power. Fully integrative approaches-those that cross multiple between-subjects factors-are resource-intensive, often requiring prohibitively large samples (e.g., Almaatouq et al., 2021;Awad et al., 2018;Baribault et al., 2018;. The present semi-integrative design avoids such factorial complexity, deliberating attempting to balance inferential potential and practical feasibility. Our sample size of ~1,200 participants-well within the bounds of contemporary behavioral research-was sufficient to detect both average treatment effects and heterogeneity in those effects of moderate to large magnitude. For instance, we were well powered to detect increases in sharing quality, of approximately 3 to 4 percentage points. By striking a balance between real-world complexity and experimental feasibility, semi-integrative approaches may offer a scalable, efficient way to deepen our understanding of human decision-making across diverse settings.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: No single experimental approach can capture all dimensions, and the approach we applied is no exception. Certain parameters were beyond the scope of our study, leaving open questions for future research. For instance, we did not examine how the data collection platform might influence results-participants' intention to share false news can vary significantly across platforms (e.g., Lucid vs. Prolific; Martel & Rand, 2023b). Similarly, while our news stimuli varied along dimensions such as sensationalism and political leaning, these dimensions are far from fully representative. The tested interventions also leave room for further discussion. For example, in the media literacy intervention, we could have manipulated the number of tips provided, and in the accuracy prompt intervention, increasing the number of headlines participants evaluated may have led to more credible effects (as found in Fazio et al., 2024). Expanding the parameter space around false news interventions remains an important direction for future research, offering further opportunities to refine, optimize, and generalize intervention strategies.

While our study examined effect modification (i.e., how individual-and item-level characteristics relate to treatment effects), we did not test causal interactions. This limits the generalizability of our findings to other populations, particularly outside the U.S., where different causal mechanisms may shape false news sharing and intervention effectiveness (Bareinboim & Pearl, 2016;Deffner, Rohrer, & McElreath, 2022). That said, even non-causal associations between intervention effects and third variables are valuable for both researchers and practitioners, providing crucial guidance on who might benefit the most from a given intervention (as long as the distribution of covariates in the target population reasonably resembles the studied sample; Rohrer et al., 2022).

News sharing behavior in our task was simulated, with participants making explicit "share" vs. "not share" decisions for each news item. This reflects their immediate sharing intention in a controlled setting, which differs from real-world social media environments, where factors like audience composition, reputational concerns, platform algorithms, and social feedback influence what people ultimately share. While we use the term "false news sharing," it is important to note that sharing decisions in controlled experiments may not fully capture real-world sharing behavior.

Additionally, our task presented an equal number of true and false news trials, an artificial balance that differs from real-world veracity base rates (Orchinik et al., 2023). Although self-reported sharing intentions and lab-based sharing decisions are commonly used as proxies in misinformation research, relatively few studies have tested how well these proxies map onto real-world sharing. Providing some support for their validity, self-reported willingness to share political news in online surveys correlates well with actual social media sharing behavior (Mosleh et al., 2020) News sharing behavior in our task was simulated, with an equal number of true and false news trials-an artificial balance that likely differs from real-world veracity base rates (Orchinik et al., 2023). Additionally, sharing behavior in our controlled setting may not fully capture the complexities of real-world social media environments, where factors such as the social relationship between the poster and the sharer, the size of a user's audience, and the demographic composition of their followers can all influence sharing decisions. That said, prior research suggests that self-reported willingness to share political news in online surveys correlates well with actual sharing behavior on social media (Mosleh et al., 2020), providing some confidence that our findings generalize to real-world settings.

The observed effectiveness of the tested interventions may also be shaped by external factors that were not accounted for in our study. For instance, false news interventions may elicit varying levels of resistance across different subgroups, differ in how engaging they are, and produce effects that vary in longevity. Media literacy tips, in particular, require more time and effort from users, which could limit their adoption outside a controlled study setting. However, as a boosting intervention (e.g., Kozyreva et al., 2022), media literacy may have a more lasting impact on sharing quality compared to interventions that rely on external cues, such as warning labels.

Additionally, our study did not examine whether the interventions differentially influenced how participants processed specific aspects of news items-such as headline titles, associated images, or source credibility. Future research should explore these finer-grained components of news evaluation to better understand the mechanisms driving intervention effects.

Our findings are limited to psychologically informed, individual-level interventions and do not speak to the effectiveness of system-level interventions. Addressing the spread of misinformation at scale is unlikely to be achieved through individual-focused strategies alone, as the underlying causes are largely systemic. Long-term behavioral change may require broader interventions, such as regulatory actions or platform design modifications (Chater & Loewenstein, 2022). That said, individual-level interventions-such as labels, prompts, and media literacy tips-can still play a meaningful role in improving news sharing quality, particularly in the absence of systemic reforms. Our findings highlight how different interventions, when applied individually, influence sharing behavior, including among high-risk subpopulations (Budak et al., 2024;Brashier, 2024). Future research should explore how individual-and system-level interventions interact, assessing whether their combined implementation offers a complementary and more effective approach to mitigating misinformation (Bode & Vraga, 2021).

Some research suggests that a significant share of misinformation is spread by well-known, verified, and highly influential users (e.g., DeVerna et al., 2022;Grinberg et al., 2019). While our sample included only participants who reported actively sharing news on social media, it is unlikely that it captured these high-profile accounts. Additionally, real-world misinformation spread is shaped by external forces-such as algorithmic amplification-that may constrain the effectiveness of applying these interventions at scale. Given these limitations, caution is warranted when extrapolating our findings to broader real-world contexts. The feasibility of implementing these interventions at scale remains uncertain, particularly in environments where misinformation is driven more strongly by structural and algorithmic dynamics than individual decision-making.

We examined the effects of interventions on false news claims with low plausibility, following the sampling approach of . Blatantly false claims represent a significant category of misinformation; their real-world relevance is underscored by field data showing that highly implausible articles from low-quality news sources are often widely shared (Stewart et al., 2021)-potentially because individuals endorse the general "gist" of their content rather than their literal accuracy (Langdon et al., 2024). Experimental evidence further suggests that, once exposed, false claims can exert strong and harmful effects on behavioral intentions (Allen et al., 2024). That said, our study did not examine misleading (rather than outright false) claims, which can still misinform and shape public beliefs. And, such content may be more impactful in practice. For instance, Allen et al. (2024) find that vaccine-skeptical news articles that are technically accurate but misleading (e.g., a headline stating, "Healthy doctor dies after receiving a COVID-19 vaccine") receive significantly more views on Facebook than blatantly false vaccine-skeptical content. Given their higher exposure rates, misleading claims may exert a greater cumulative influence on public attitudes and behaviors than outright falsehoods. Future research should examine how misinformation-targeting interventions-such as those tested here-perform against content that is technically true but misleading, as well as against false claims that vary in plausibility. Understanding how intervention efficacy differs across these categories will provide a more complete picture of how to combat misinformation in complex, real-world settings.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Although many studies have examined false news sharing, there has been no broad, comparative, and computational analysis of this harmful behavior and the interventions designed to mitigate it. We addressed this gap by applying a semi-integrative experimental approach to false news sharing. Our approach revealed the comparative efficacy of multiple false news interventions, whether and how individual-and item-level characteristics shape false news sharing and intervention effectiveness, and the decision-making processes underlying all these effects. In doing so, we uncovered key insights into false news sharing, such as that existing interventions appear effective across numerous individual and content characteristics-including among significant risk factors, such as political conservatism. Though these insights contribute to ongoing efforts to curb false news sharing, intervention-based strategies alone are unlikely to be sufficient.

Substantial changes to the information ecosystem, such as the automated removal of false content and stricter enforcement against repeat offenders, are likely necessary to meaningfully reduce false news spread and influence.

The observed drift rate against sharing news was particularly pronounced, for instance, for individuals identifying as female (β = 0.06, CI = [0.01, 0.11], ER >100), more liberal participants (β = 0.09, CI = [0.06, 0.11], ER >100), and for politically non-congruent news (β = 0.19, CI = [0.17, 0.20], ER >100). The influence of news accuracy (sharing quality) on the drift was stronger, for instance, for more liberal participants (β = 0.06, CI = [0.03, 0.08], ER >100), participants higher in analytical thinking (β = 0.04, CI = [0.01, 0.06], ER >100), and participants with greater political knowledge (β = 0.07, CI = [0.04, 0.09], ER >100). The boundary separation also varied as a function of several individual-level characteristics (Figure 7A). figure.head: Accuracy
figure.figDesc: Prompt Intervention. The accuracy prompt did not impact the starting point (β = 0.00, CI = [−0.10, 0.10], ER = 1, Figure 8A). And, while the accuracy prompt increased drift rate towards overall sharing (β = 0.06, CI = [0.01, 0.11], ER = 60.7), it did not increase the drift rate towards sharing quality, though the observed effect was directionally in line with past research (β = 0.02, CI = [−0.05, 0.09], ER = 2.2;

figure.head: Warning
figure.figDesc: Label Intervention. The warning label intervention shifted participants' starting point towards less sharing overall (β = -0.28, CI = [-0.38, -0.17], ER >100; Figure 8A), and towards greater sharing quality (β = 0.39, CI = [0.30, 0.47], ER >100). In contrast, and likely due to their large impact on the starting point, warning labels had limited influence on the deliberation process-drift rate and boundary separation-despite the news items and warnings labels being present throughout the entire decision-making process (drift rate towards sharing quality: β = 0.04, CI = [−0.05, 0.12], ER = 4.8; boundary separation: β = 0.00, CI = [−0.04, 0.05], ER = 1.3; Figure 8B-C). The estimated DDM parameters varied as a function of several individual-level characteristics (Figure 8; Table S6). For instance, more conservative and less educated participants incorporated the warning labels less via the starting point (political leaning: β = −0.16, CI = [−0.24, −0.07], ER >100; education: β = 0.12, CI = [0.04, 0.20], , ER >100; Figure 8A) and more so via the drift rate (political leaning: β = 0.13, CI = [0.05, 0.21], ER >100; education: β = −0.11, CI = [−0.19, −0.04], ER >100;Figure 8B). Thus, they tended to continuously assess the news items in light of the warning label being present or absent. Finally, the drift rate towards sharing quality was also particularly pronounced for items that aligned with participants' political orientation (political congruence; β = 0.08, CI = [0.01, 0.15], ER >67.0;Figure 8B).Social Norm Intervention. The social norm intervention did not change the starting point (β = −0.04, CI = [−0.14, 0.06], ER = 3.5;Figure 8A) but did increase news sharing quality via the drift (β = 0.08, CI = [0.02, 0.15], ER >100;Figure 8B). Participants with lower analytical thinking exhibited a particularly pronounced drift towards higher sharing quality (β = −0.09, CI = [−0.16, −0.02], ER >100;Figure 8B), indicating that intuitive thinkers were particularly likely to incorporate the normative information of the intervention when deliberating on the news items.Media LiteracyIntervention. The media literacy intervention, similar to the social norm intervention, did not change the starting point but did improve the sharing quality via drift (β = 0.24, CI = [0.17, 0.30], ER >100; Figure 8A-B), and again, this was particularly true for participants with lower analytical thinking (β = −0.07 CI = [−0.14, −0.00], ER = 53.1) and for news items that aligned with participants' political orientation (political congruence (β = 0.07, CI = [0.01, 0.13]). ). Except for this change, the conducted models mirrored the individual-level characteristics regression models (Models 1-3). Hence, we first investigated pre-intervention behavior with Model 4 (mirroring Model 1), time effects with Model 5 (mirroring Model 2), and treatment effects with Model 6 (mirroring Model 3). Similarly, the DDMs were the same as the DDMs investigating individual-level characteristics. However, we assumed that unlike individual-level characteristics, item-level characteristics can only influence the drift rate because item-level characteristics are attributes of the stimuli themselves-inferring and incorporating these characteristics is part of the information evaluation process described by the drift (seeYang & Krajbich, 2023). For a full description of the regression and DDM models, see supplemental materials.

body.note: As the conducted approach was "bottom-up" the pre-registration did not include specific hypotheses. For transparency's sake, we note that the pre-registration outlined the general analysis approach and did not include the specific model formulas.2 Failing to complete any part of the news sharing task could not have been impacted by condition, as the interventions occurred in the middle of the task itself.1 We note that the scale of this measure was not ideal, as it is somewhat unclear what 'always' indicates in terms of sharing behavior. This limitation should be considered when interpreting our findings.

We additionally assessed when and on which platform participants use social media. This measure was not included in the analysis due to its complexity. We also assessed a measure of single items (e.g., "I am a gullible person"). These items were not included in the analysis given their unknown validity and reliability, and because they were assessed solely for exploratory purposes. All other assessed measures were included in the analysis.
Inoculation or prebunking interventions were not included as they are typically much longer than the other interventions (e.g.,Roozenbeek & Van der Linden, 2019).
This is why we did not apply cross-validation or other machine learning-based analyses, which are designed for predictive accuracy rather than the description of observed experimental effects.
